— The agency told MT that its “disappointed that the New York Times has filed suit to collect the Commission’s internal web server logs, logs whose disclosure would put at jeopardy the Commission’s IT security practices for its Electronic Comment Filing System.” As John reports for Pro , the Times on Thursday filed a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit against the FCC, “alleging the agency refused to release records the newspaper sought as it probed possible Russian interference in the agency's net neutrality repeal proceeding.” According to the suit, “the FCC has thrown up a series of roadblocks, preventing The Times from obtaining the documents.”

TARIFFS TO TANK 5G?

MARK YOUR CALENDARS — The House Energy & Commerce telecom subpanel has announced a hearing for next Thursday focusing on the “State of the Media Marketplace.” Rep. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.), the panel’s chair, said in a statement it will “spotlight the latest trends in the ways Americans consume media, how that affects business models, market growth, and public policy, and where we go from here.” According to Blackburn, the panel will feature testimony from “expert witnesses,” though no names were announced.
